digest.editor_note: Fellow Humans, Europe's diplomatic traffic to Beijing is becoming something of a pilgrimage: Macron went, Starmer went, and now Merz has made the trip, business delegation in tow, to tell Xi Jinping that the €90 billion trade deficit is 'not healthy' while simultaneously cheering a 120-aircraft Airbus order. Meanwhile, Washington is quietly licensing Venezuelan oil resales to a Cuba it helped starve of fuel — the kind of policy whiplash that passes for strategy these days.

sentiment.label: Cautious
sentiment.context: Geopolitical hedging dominates — Europe pivoting toward China amid U.S. friction, courts blocking Trump deportation policy, and crypto markets struggling to hold momentum — pointing to a market environment that is watchful rather than directional.

stories.headline: Merz Courts Xi in Beijing, Airbus Deal in Hand, Trade Deficit Looming Over Talks
stories.body: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz visited Beijing on Feb. 25 with a large business delegation, telling President Xi Jinping he wants to deepen the 'comprehensive strategic partnership' — even as Germany's trade deficit with China hit €90 billion last year, up fourfold since 2020. China announced a 120-aircraft Airbus order as a goodwill gesture, but Merz was blunt that the imbalance driven by Chinese overcapacity is 'not healthy.' The visit follows Macron and Starmer to Beijing and signals Europe's deliberate hedge against a deteriorating relationship with Washington.

stories.headline: U.S. Treasury Opens Door to Venezuelan Oil Resales to Cuba as Rubio Begins Caribbean Tour
stories.body: The U.S. Treasury Department said it will authorise companies to apply for licences to resell Venezuelan oil to Cuba, reversing a supply cut that followed Washington's seizure of control over Venezuela's oil exports in January. Cuba lost its main crude supplier when the U.S. took over Venezuela's export flow, and Mexico — an interim substitute — also halted shipments in January. The move, timed to Secretary of State Marco Rubio's Caribbean visit, is conditional: transactions must support the Cuban private sector and cannot benefit Cuban military or government institutions.

stories.headline: Federal Judge Rules Trump's Third-Country Deportation Policy Unlawful, Grants 15-Day Stay
stories.body: U.S. District Judge Brian E. Murphy ruled Wednesday that the Trump administration's policy of deporting migrants to third countries with which they have no connection violates due process, finding that the policy 'extinguishes valid challenges by effecting removal before those challenges can be raised.' Murphy suspended his ruling for 15 days to allow a government appeal — the same case in which the Supreme Court's conservative majority previously paused his earlier decision, clearing a flight to South Sudan. The ruling adds fresh legal turbulence to an immigration enforcement agenda that already faces multiple active injunctions.

stories.headline: Nigeria's NRS Targets N40.7 Trillion in 2026 Revenue After Beating 2025 Goal by N3 Trillion
stories.body: Nigeria's National Revenue Service Executive Chairman Zacch Adedeji told the House of Representatives Appropriations Committee that the agency is targeting N40.7 trillion in combined tax, petroleum, and mineral revenue for 2026, up from N28.23 trillion actually collected in 2025 — which itself was N3 trillion above target. Growth was driven overwhelmingly by non-oil taxes, which came in N3.4 trillion above projection, while oil tax revenues missed by 5.2%. The 2026 target assumes oil production rising from 1.7 to 1.8 million barrels per day and reflects structural reforms transferring petroleum royalties to NRS.

stories.headline: XRP Gains 8% as Bitcoin and Ethereum Sentiment Cools; $1,300 Targets Circulate
stories.body: XRP rose 8.19% in 24 hours to trade at $1.46, outperforming Bitcoin and Ethereum as on-chain analytics firm Santiment flagged that bullish commentary toward the two leading assets has dropped sharply from the prior week. Analyst ChartNerd identified $1.50 as the critical level for continuation toward $1.80, warning that failure there could see a retraction to $1.20–$1.30. More exuberant calls — including a Fibonacci extension target of $1,300 per coin — are circulating in retail communities, a reliable indicator that the speculative fringe is growing louder as fundamentals remain mixed.

stories.headline: GO Residential REIT Acquires Three NYC Apartment Towers for $380.5 Million
stories.body: GO Residential REIT is under contract to buy Ivy Tower at 350 West 43rd Street from Friedman Management for $150.5 million, and two Hudson Yards towers — 411 and 444 West 35th Street — from Maddd Equities and Joy Construction for $230 million. The combined 624-unit portfolio was funded through cash and stock, with Newmark's Adam Spies and Doug Harmon representing sellers and now seeking at least 50% leverage on acquisition financing. The deals signal continued institutional appetite for New York multifamily assets despite elevated rate conditions.

stories.headline: Australia's Chalmers Faces 'Inflation Denial' Charge as Election Pressure Mounts
stories.body: Australia's shadow treasurer accused Treasurer Jim Chalmers of being in 'denial' over inflation, sharpening pre-election economic lines as the Albanese government navigates an uncomfortable period of domestic controversy including a diplomatic spat over comments about activist Grace Tame. Mortgage rates reportedly hitting their lowest level since 2022 adds a complicating variable for the government's narrative heading into a pivotal political stretch. The inflation debate mirrors tensions in other developed economies where central bank credibility and cost-of-living politics are increasingly inseparable.

quote.text: The market can stay irrational longer than you can stay solvent.
quote.editor_note: Fellow Humans, the Federal Reserve has quietly handed bank supervision to a man who spent four decades representing the banks he'll now police — and the market, characteristically, has other things to worry about. Circle's stablecoin revenue is up 77%, Reliance and Meta are formalizing their AI joint venture, and somewhere in Albuquerque a streamer is planning to put pizza on a roof. We cover what matters.

sentiment.label: Cautious
sentiment.context: A mix of regulatory capture concerns at the Fed, crypto resilience amid broader market softness, and AI investment uncertainty keeps sentiment in cautious territory.

stories.headline: Fed Appoints Career Wall Street Lawyer Randall Guynn to Head Bank Supervision
stories.body: The Federal Reserve board has named Randall Guynn — a nearly 40-year veteran of Davis Polk & Wardwell's Financial Institutions Group — as director of supervision and regulation, effective March 8. The appointment breaks a tradition dating to at least 1977 of filling the role with career Fed staff. Critics, including Better Markets CEO Dennis Kelleher, have described the move as regulatory capture in plain sight, arguing that Guynn's entire professional history was spent representing the very institutions he will now oversee.

stories.headline: Circle Posts 77% Revenue Surge, USDC Circulation Up 72% Year-on-Year
stories.body: Circle reported fourth-quarter revenue growth of 77% year-on-year, sending shares up 23% in morning trading despite a prolonged slump in broader crypto markets. USDC in circulation hit a market cap of approximately $75 billion, with Visa and Polymarket among new infrastructure adopters. Analysts at CFRA warn that sustaining performance will require navigating Federal Reserve rate compression and a rapidly crowding stablecoin competitive landscape.

stories.headline: Meta Takes 30% Stake in Reliance's AI Arm for Rs 256.6 Crore
stories.body: Reliance Industries has completed the stake allotment in Reliance Enterprise Intelligence Ltd, with Facebook Overseas acquiring 30% for Rs 256.6 crore and Reliance Intelligence holding the remaining 70% for Rs 596.6 crore. The joint venture, first announced at RIL's August 2025 AGM, will deploy Meta's open-source Llama models across enterprise AI services leveraging Reliance's distribution network. The deal closes as Nifty IT has shed roughly 20% in February alone and questions mount over whether enterprise AI investments will generate meaningful returns.

stories.headline: Fermi Inc. Faces Securities Class Action Over AI Data Center IPO Misrepresentations
stories.body: Law firm Hagens Berman has issued a deadline notice for the March 6 lead plaintiff filing in a securities class action against Fermi Inc. (NASDAQ: FRMI), alleging the company misrepresented demand for its 'Project Matador' AI data center campus during its October 2025 IPO. The complaint centers on a December 12 disclosure that the campus's anchor tenant had terminated a $150 million construction financing agreement, triggering a near-34% single-day stock decline. The case adds to growing scrutiny over AI infrastructure companies that raised capital on bullish demand projections.

stories.headline: Luxury Retailers Recalibrate as High Earners Show Paycheck-to-Paycheck Stress
stories.body: PYMNTS Intelligence data reveals that nearly half of U.S. consumers earning above $100,000 annually report living paycheck to paycheck, with more than a third of those earning above $200,000 saying the same. Luxury brands are responding by emphasizing value narratives and expanding buy-now-pay-later options, a structural shift that complicates the traditional assumption of affluent consumers as a reliable demand floor. Moody's Analytics Chief Economist Mark Zandi notes the spending gap between income cohorts 'has never been wider,' concentrating consumption growth at the very top of the income distribution.

stories.headline: Jalisco Violence Hits Puerto Vallarta Airbnb Hosts as Cancellations Begin
stories.body: An Airbnb operator managing three properties in Puerto Vallarta reports receiving cancellations following the recent outbreak of cartel violence in Jalisco, which forced guests to shelter in place and drew international travel advisories. The host, who manages a mix of owned and arbitrage rentals generating at least half her income, says bookings remain in place for now but the medium-term pipeline is uncertain. The episode is an early data point on how security incidents in Mexico translate into measurable tourism and short-term rental revenue losses.

stories.headline: UK Parliamentary Speaker Alerted Police to Peter Mandelson Flight Risk Before Arrest
stories.body: Peter Mandelson was arrested at his north London home on suspicion of misconduct in public office, with the UK parliamentary speaker having tipped off police over concerns he might flee. Mandelson, a senior figure in New Labour and former EU trade commissioner, has held prominent advisory and diplomatic roles in recent years. The arrest adds political turbulence to the UK's institutional landscape at a moment when its transatlantic relationships are already under pressure.
